verses.verse: (Isaiah Reassures King Ahaz) (2 Kings 15.25, 37; 16.1) In the days of Ahaz son of Jotham son of Uzziah, king of Judah, King Rezin of Aram and King Pekah son of Remaliah of Israel went up to attack Jerusalem but could not conquer it.

(v 13|ISA 7:13; Isa 8.12) When the house of David heard that Aram had allied itself with Ephraim, the heart of Ahaz (Heb his heart) and the heart of his people shook as the trees of the forest shake before the wind.

(2 Kings 18.17; Isa 10.21) Then the LORD said to Isaiah, “Go out to meet Ahaz, you and your son Shear-jashub, (That is, a remnant shall return) at the end of the conduit of the upper pool on the highway to the fuller’s field,

(Isa 10.24; 30.15; 35.4) and say to him: Take heed, be quiet, do not fear, and do not let your heart be faint because of these two smoldering stumps of firebrands, because of the fierce anger of Rezin and Aram and the son of Remaliah.
Because Aram—with Ephraim and the son of Remaliah—has plotted evil against you, saying,
‘Let us go up against Judah and terrify it (Or cut it off) and conquer it for ourselves and make the son of Tabeel king in it’;
(Isa 8.10) therefore thus says the Lord GOD: It shall not stand, and it shall not come to pass.
(Isa 17.1-3) For the head of Aram is Damascus, and the head of Damascus is Rezin. (Within sixty-five years Ephraim will be shattered, no longer a people.)
(2 Chr 20.20) The head of Ephraim is Samaria, and the head of Samaria is the son of Remaliah. If you do not stand firm in faith, you shall not stand at all.”
(Isaiah Gives Ahaz the Sign of Immanuel) Again the LORD spoke to Ahaz, saying,
(2 Kings 19.29; Isa 37.30; 38.7, 8) “Ask a sign of the LORD your God; let it be deep as Sheol or high as heaven.”
But Ahaz said, “I will not ask, and I will not put the LORD to the test.”
Then Isaiah (Heb he) said, “Hear then, O house of David! Is it too little for you to weary mortals that you weary my God also?
(Isa 8.8; 9.6; Mt 1.23; Lk 1.31) Therefore the Lord himself will give you a sign. Look, the young woman is with child and shall bear a son and shall name him Immanuel. (That is, God is with us)
(v 22) He shall eat curds and honey by the time he knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good.
(Isa 8.4) For before the child knows how to refuse the evil and choose the good, the land before whose two kings you are in dread will be deserted.
(1 Kings 12.16; 2 Chr 28.19) The LORD will bring on you and on your people and on your ancestral house such days as have not come since the day that Ephraim departed from Judah—the king of Assyria.”
(Isa 5.26) On that day the LORD will whistle for the fly that is at the sources of the streams of Egypt and for the bee that is in the land of Assyria.
(Isa 2.19; Jer 16.16) And they will all come and settle in the steep ravines and in the clefts of the rocks and on all the thornbushes and on all the watering holes. (Meaning of Heb uncertain)

(Isa 8.7; 10.5, 15; 24.1; Ezek 5.1-4) On that day the Lord will shave with a razor hired beyond the River—with the king of Assyria—the head and the hair of the feet, and it will take off the beard as well.
On that day one will keep alive a young cow and two sheep
and will eat curds because of the abundance of milk that they give, for everyone left in the land shall eat curds and honey.
On that day every place where there used to be a thousand vines, worth a thousand shekels of silver, will become briers and thorns.
With bow and arrows one will go there, for all the land will be briers and thorns,
and as for all the hills that used to be hoed with a hoe, you will not go there for fear of briers and thorns, but they will become a place where cattle are let loose and where sheep tread.
